rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Pressure, volume, temperature, and density relations in the critical region. --.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: For over one hundred years experiments and observations have been made on the so called 'critical' change of a liquid to a gas. No adequate explanation of all the phenomena has yet appeared. Some investigators cling to the classical picture of this transition. They believe that a liquid differs from a gas by degree only, and hold that when the critical change occurs the two phases are physically identical. Anomalous behaviour, which has been observed, would be attributed to impurities, gravitational effects, and other extraneous factors. On the other hand, an increasing amount of evidence has been, and is being presented, in favour of a structural concept of the liquid state. Many suggestions as to the nature of the liquid have been presented but most agree that it differs from the gaseous state in kind as well as degree. Studies of the critical temperature-critical pressure region, where the two phases interchange, have been most fruitful in obtaining data on the nature of the differences between them. [...] Dynamic structure hypotheses have been satisfactory in explaining many of the critical phenomena. Among the most satisfactory of these is the theory of Regional Orientation developed by Maass and his co-workers. [...] The experiments described in this thesis give further support to this picture of the liquid state and have led the author to suggest a mechanism for the phase transformations in the critical region. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The acid solubility of the inorganic phosphate of Quebec soils.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The action of acids on the phosphorus compounds of the soil is probably one of the oldest processes studied by soil investigators. [...] The plant is believed to absorb its phosphorus as inorganic phosphate, and hence a study of the soluble inorganic fraction would seem to be of great practical importance. According to this view the decomposable organic fraction must be mineralized in the soil to inorganic form in order to be used by the plant. Therefore the uptake of phosphorus by plants is likely to be regulated by the nature of the soil inorganic phosphorus complex. [...] Since soils are the product of the weathering of rock materials, and, under similar conditions of climate, develop similar chemical and physical characteristics, it is easily conceivable that the phosphorus compounds of individual soils may be characteristic of the weathering to which they have been subjected. [...] Could we not, then, construct acid solubility curves for soil phosphate which would be characteristic of soils of the same type? If such curves can be constructed, then from a knowledge of the chemical and physical composition of the soil, its previous history and the shape of the curves, it should be possible to deduce further information regarding the manner in which phosphorus is combined with the soil constituents. [...] The purpose of this investigation was to find out if the construction of such curves was feasible [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An investigation of the effect of oxygen content on the rate of dissolution of gold in cyanide solutions. --.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The cyanide process has for its object, the commercially profitable recovery of gold from its ores. This is accomplished by the solvent action of an alkaline cyanide solution on the precious metal. This process is complex and if the mechanism of the solution of gold is clearly understood today it is within very recent years that this understanding has been achieved. The variables in the cyanide process have been the subject of much research but there is one which has received less than its due share of attention: the oxygen content of the solution. Holmes (1) states that "it has been established beyond possibility of doubt that the presence of oxygen is necessary for the solution of gold in aqueous potassium cyanide." Little work, however, has been done on the effects of increased oxygen concentration on the rate of dissolution of gold. The investigators undertook to determine some of these effects in the hope of modifying the standard cyanide process to obtain more rapid and more economical extraction of gold from its ores. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Metallurgy.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The structure of lignin. --.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: For many years past, investigations have been carried out in an attempt to determine the structure of lignin, a constituent of nearly all plants. The importance of lignin and the role which it plays in plant life is not yet clearly understood. But its significance from the industrial and economic aspect can hardly be overestimated. For in the processes developed for the isolation of cellulose from various woods and grasses, there are obtained simultaneously large quantities of lignin. This lignin waste amounts to approximately one ton out of every four tons of wood used in the manufacture of sulfite pulp. Large scale industrial use of this lignin has so far met with only slight success. It is hoped that when the chemical structure of lignin is elucidated, it will be possible to prevent this vast economic waste. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The chemical and physical properties of hydrogen peroxide - nitric acid solutions. --.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The work to be described in the following pages may be conveniently divided into two parts, the first section dealing with various chemical reactions resulting from the action of hydrogen peroxide-- nitric acid mixtures on organic compounds and identification of the products obtained, the second with physical measurements of hydrogen peroxide mixtures, principally of refractive index. The latter part is somewhat preliminary in nature, the ultimate aim being to obtain a means of determining the structure of hydrogen peroxide and the various peracids which are formed by its action upon different acids, both organic and inorganic. The refractive index measurements were undertaken owing to several accidents experienced by the author and also due to his marked sensitivity to several organic compounds which were investigated. Thus in some instances, products were obtained which could not be further identified. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some factors affecting fat and vitamin : a metabolism of fowl with specific reference to the effect of the anterior pituitary.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Animal Nutrition and Breeding
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: An attempt has been made to advance the knowledge with respect to factors affecting fat and Vitamin A metabolism in the domestic fowl through a study of the effect of a saline extract of the anterior pituitary. An extended bibliography on the available information pertaining to this subject is presented and a specific project has been carried out to show the effect of different levels of extract for prolonged injection periods on Vitamin A and fat metabolism, general body condition and changes in endocrine glands. Immature Single Comb White Leghorn cockerels were used as experimental subjects. Under the stimulation of a saline extract of the raw anterior pituitary the fat stores of the body were rapdily depleted, resulting in a noticeable decrease in body weight. There was a very definite decrease in liver, Vitamin A and carotene. An increase in blood acetone was noted. The results are both of a supplementary and a confirmatory nature.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Animal Nutrition and Breeding.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Geology of Calumet mines, ltd.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The lead and zinc deposit described in this thesis is at Calumet Island, Pontiac County, Province of Quebec, about fifty-eight miles northwest of Ottawa. The deposit occurs on the southwestern part of the island, on lots 3 to 12, range IV. The railroad station near the island is Campbell's Bay, on the north shore of the channel, on a branch line of the Canadian Pacific Railway. From this station a four mile motor road runs south to Bryson where a bridge crosses to the island. Campbell's Bay can be reached by a ferry from Calumet Island village. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A pre-Shaksperian drama in pre-Shaksperian and in modern times.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The main body of this study consists of a comparison and a contrast of the various aspects of the drama in pre-Shaksperian or medieval days with those same aspects of the modern theatre. This, in itself, is but a means towards an end. I have attempted to show that what appealed to theatre-goers of one generation can also appeal to a succeding generation; that it is possible to transplant a specific art form from its own essential background and, with minor modifications and changes in its material, still find for it a sympathetic and appreciative public. In other words, by using a representative medieval drama as an example, I have tried to prove that audiences through the ages have not changed fundamentally, and that our early English theatre, though often neglected, produced plays worthy to be remembered. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: ENGLISH DRAMA -- HISTORY AND CRITICISM

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The hydrolysis of propionitrile by strong acids. : Secret (war work).
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A study of the strong acid catalysed hydrolysis of nitriles has been undertaken for propionitrile, with hydrobromic, nitric, and sulphuric acids. The kinetics of the reaction are similar to those found by previous investigators for hydrochloric acid. It was found that the rate of hydrolysis is not independent of the decomposition of the intermediate amide at acid concentration above five normal. A decrease in the activation energy with increase in acid concentration was found for all acids.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The distribution of sensory nerves to the dura matter and cerebral vessels.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: For almost a century it has been a well established anatomical fact that the cerebral dura mater and the larger cerebral blood vessels have an abundant nerve supply. Starting with the classical researches of Claude Bernard in the middle of the nineteenth century, scientific interest has been devoted chiefly to the investigation of the functions of the cranial vasomotor nerves, and this interest has continued to the present day in the studies of Cobb, Forbes, and their associates on the vasomotor control of cerebral circulation in health and disease. However, it is only very recently that the afferent nerves supplying intracranial structures have been studied intensively, and serious attempts made to correlate the anatomy of afferent nerves with clinical problems of head pain. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Effects of acidity on growth, structure and physiology of plants with special reference to root cells.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In the past 25 years considerable controversy has taken place over the effect of Hydrogen-ion concentration on plant growth. In 1931 Hoagland (37) expressed the following: "I recall some early experiments with, barley seedlings in California. With considerable surprise it was noted that the plants made better development in a definitely acid solution than in a slightly alkaline one. The impression gained from the literature of that time was to the • effect that most agricultural plants round their most favourable environment in a slightly alkaline medium and were injured by acidity". Following the discrediting by various investigators of this early ·belief of the harmful effects of acidity there was a tendency to treat the Hydrogen-ion concentration of the soils as the prime factor controlling the growth and distribution of plants. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Plant morphology.
Roots (Botany)
Growth (Plants)

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of the Genera Callarcitia and Apantesis.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The moths dealt with in this paper are showy and attractive, and have long been favourites with collectors. Nevertheless, their classification presents great difficulties, and notwithstanding the extensive body of literature that has grown up, there has been no satisfactoty revision of the group, and, indeed, no detailed study has appeared since Hampson's Catalogue of the Lepidoptera Phalaenae in 1901. Ndss Smith's recent revision, while based on very extensive studies, has appeared only in abstract form, and is consequently of little value to one unfamiliar with the group. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Callarcitia

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on vitamin A and carotene.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In 1920 Hopkins (1) demonstrated that vitamin A was inactivated in the presence of atmospheric oxygen at elevated temperatures, although little or no effect could be observed at room temperatures or in the absence of air. During the same year Drummond and Coward (2) showed that butter exposed to air at 37°C lost a considerable portion of its vitamin A potency. Frequent confirmations of this early work have been obtained both for vitamin A itself and for its precursors, although the latter are apparently more stable than is the actual vitamin (3). [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: André Gide et le communisme.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Pour celui qui ne connaît Gide que de nom, ou qui n'a lu que quelques-unes de ses oeuvres sa conversion au communisme apparaît comme une flagrante dénonciation de sa pensée. Car Gide a toujours été le partisan de l'individualisme outré, le dillettante soucieux de développer sa personnalité, désireux de vivre selon sa guise et méprisant la société dans laquelle il vivait. Certes de telles dispositions ne semblent nullement conciliables à première vue avec les doctrines communistes. Et cependant sa conversion est-elle si surprenant-e? Le chemin qu'il suivait ne devait-il pas l'amener tôt ou tard au communisme? Ne peut-on retracer le chemin suivi par Gide et y relever les indices qui pouvaient faire prévoir cette transformation? Gide ne s'est presque pas préoccupé des questions sociales ou politiques. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Communism -- France.
Gide, André, 1869-1951.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Development and effects of Strongyloides Papillosus (Wedl, 1856) in rodents.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Strongyloides is a genus of minute, parasitic, gastro-intestinal nematodes which occur in many animals including man. It is characterized by a bisexual parasitic phase alternating with a larval stage outside of the host. The external phase of the life cycle has the larval progeny developing directly into forms infective for a new host. In addition to this, Strongyloides may have a true free-living generation composed of adult rhabditiform males and females, which reproduce sexually and give rise to filariform larvae which are also infective for a new host. Another distinguishing peculiarity of Strongyloides species is the fact that the parasitic stage in the intestine is represented only by female worms thought to be syngonic or parthenogenic. The female lays thin shelled, embryonated eggs which pass out with the faeces and under suitable moisture and temperature conditions, either by direct or indirect development, develop into minute infective larva. The infective larva are able to penetrate the skin of the host and are carried by the blood to the lungs and being coughed up are swallowed and finally reach the intestine to develop into the parasitic female form. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Parasitology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The prevention of meningocerebral adhesions.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The importance of this study on the prevention of meningocerebral adhesions, with a view to a lowering of the incidence of posttraumatic epilepsy, is modified, therefore, by acceptance or rejection of the adhesion hypothesis. The solution to the problem requires adoption of a proven method for the prevention of adhesions, employing the technique in the treatment of craniocerebral wounds in the present. conflict and, finally, an analysis of the incidence of posttraumatic epilepsy in patients so treated in later years.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurosurgery.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on blood coagulation.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A review is presented of the various theories of blood coagulation from the time of A.Schmidt to the present day. The various factors of the coagulation process are discussed in detail. A section has been devoted to a review of anticoagulants, and haemorrhagic diathesis from various causes is discussed in the light of recent findings. In the preservation of blood, fibrin makes its appearance in the samples despite the presence of an anticoagulant. The experimental work, has been conducted on samples from the Blood Bank of the Biochemistry Department. It has been of an exploratory nature to determine the cause of fibrin precipitation and to find a means of completely preventing or at least delaying its appearance. The results of these investigations as well as the probable causes of fibrin precipitation are discussed.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The construction and some applications of an electrically driven ultracentrifuge.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The construction and operation of a vacuum ultracentrifuge are described. The duralumin rotor carries up to 96 cc of material for centrifugation. It is driven by a two phase induction motor supplied by a 1 kw audiofrequency generator, also described. The rotor is suspended from the armature, in vacuo, by a flexible stainless steel shaft. The whole rotating system is supported by an electromagnet. With this drive the rotor has been accelerated to 30,000 RPM in 13 minutes, with 1 kw power input. With 400 watts input and no attention from the operator, the speed remained within 3.1% of this figure for nine hours. By reversing the current, the system was brought to rest in & minutes, with only 300 watts applied. The centrifuge has been used for a preliminary study of the molecular weight of lignin dissolved in ethanol. The effects of high centrifugal fields on living cells are also described.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The nitration of paraffin hydrocarbons.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Although nitration is one of the oldest reactions employed in organic chemistry, relatively little is known about its mechanism. Virtually no work has appeared on the mechanism of direct nitration of alkanes, and even though a great number of papers which deal with the nitration of aromatic compounds and alkenes have been published, the nature of these reactions is still obscure. The following review will be confined to the nitration of paraffin hydrocarbons, and will refer to other reactions only when it is necessary to elucidate. Saturated paraffin hydrocarbons have come to be regarded as extremely stable compounds which are not easily attacked by chemical reagents, and although in some measure this is true, it is probable that the emphasis is unjustified. The fundamental difference between saturated and unsaturated hydrocarbons is that the former yield only substitution products whereas the latter may give both addition and substitution products [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A psychological study of dictators.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In 1914 the most devastating and horrible orgy of bloodshed that the world had ever known broke out in the form of the World War. No corner of the earth escaped the effects of this mighty conflict, and as a result of it, the lives of millions of people were blotted out and the generations to come seriously affected. This Great War was fought 'to make the world safe for democracy' and though no one even dreamed of it---safe also for Dictatorships.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dictators
Politics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The tax systems of Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In contrast with their American contemporaries, Canadian economists have paid surprisingly little attention to the field of taxation. The last general study of Canadian taxation is Dr. Vineberg's monograph on provincial and local taxation, dated 1912. A fairly exhaustive search of the Canadian economics literature has revealed isolated articles on special phases of taxation by such scholars as my former teacher, Dr. W. c. Kierstead, Professors H. R. Kemp and D. C. MacGregor. Various Royal Commissions have prepared reports on the tax problem, some of which are superficial, others excellent as far as they go. The legal aspect of property and income taxes and succession duties has been com)letely covered by lawyers Manning, Plaxton and Quigg. The Canadian Manufacturers' Association has prepared a competent legal description of the federal sales tax. But nowhere was there a study which brought together a picture of the federal, provincial and municipal tax systems. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Plant introduction and landscape change in Barbados, 1625-1830.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Since Charles Darwin' s voyage of botanical exploration in H. M. S. "Beagle", the flora of oceanic islands has stimulated a curiosity among biogeographers out of all proportion to their size. Because true oceanic islands in effect represent field laboratories, in which changing ecological conditions may be observed within strict limitations of area, and frequently of time, if the dates of alien introductions are known, much of the interest has focussed upon ecological conflicts between those species which are endemic to the island's flora, and those which have been introduced either accidentally, or purposefully by man. In particular, man's role as an important agent of change in the ecological balance of many islands is well documented; man disturbs the vegetation through removing species by felling or burning, developing his agriculture, and introducing alien species of plants or of animals, which may act as an additional stimulus to change. Under such conditions, aggressive species of plants may come to dominate a landscape, although the extent to which this dominance is permanent is by no means certain. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Landscape changes -- Barbados -- History.
Plant introduction -- Barbados -- History.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Les livrets d’opéra du dix-neuvième siècle tirés des chefs d’oeuvre de la littérature française.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: En feuilletant une revue il y a quelques années, j'ai été frappée d'une phrase dans laquelle l'auteur mentionnait un ou deux opéras tirés de la littérature française. Comme la musique m'intéresse tout particulièrement, je me suis sentie tentée de faire des recherches sur ce sujet. En voici le résultat partiel; le nombre est fort grand des livrets d'opéra, fameux ou peu connus, dont le sujet est emprunté à la littérature française. J'ai dû alors me limiter au dix-neuvième siècle, la période la plus féconde pour l'opéra. A cause de la Guerre, j'ai dû faire toutes mes recherches aux Etats-Unis et au Canada. Je n'ai donc pas pu obtenir quelques articles parus dans des revues françaises et qui me semblant être assez importantes pour ma thèse. Toutefois, la biblopgraphie des livres sur l'opéra est si abondante, que j'ai dû y faire choix des ouvrages qui paraissaient les mieux adaptés à mon sujet. J'ai cru bon d'inclure dans ce travail une courte esquisse de l'histoire de l'opéra et surtout du livret, au dix-septième et au dix-huitième siècles. Pour le dix-neuvième, j'ai fait une étude chronologique des livrets tirés de la littérature française [...] Parceque la liste des livrets d'origine française est longue et que plusiers librettistes Italiens se sont servis d'oeuvres littéraires françaises, j'ai conclu à la grande importance des livrets français. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French literature -- 19th century.
Music -- 19th century -- History and criticism.
Operas -- Librettos.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The social and political theories of John Ruskin. --.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Within a hundred years after the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, dating from the accession of George III in 1760, England had completely changed from the dominantly agricultural country it had been for centuries before. [...] Wretchedness and misery was the lot of the labouring classes in the crowded industrial centres. Fluctuating prices and inadequate wages marked the period. The labour of women and children was on the increase. [...] So striking was the contrast that protest was inevitable. [...] In the social and political field John Ruskin was both a protest and a portent. Reacting vigorously against the individualist conceptions of man and society, he poured torrents of scorn - even of abuse on the ideas (as he imperfectly understood them) of Bentham, Ricardo, Herbert Spencer and J.S. Mill, and provided a paradox that in so doing he, a child of wealth and luxury, uttered the protest of the forgotten and dispossessed workers who had been submerged in their struggle for life and livelihood. [...] It is the purpose of these pages to sketch the outline of John Ruskin's ideas and activity in the rea1m of the social and political, without examination of his ideas on art more than is necessary to this purpose, and to indicate those of his ideas which have been since his time or seem about to be accepted in our social organization. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics -- History -- 19th century.
Ruskin, John, 1819-1900.
Great Britain -- Economic conditions -- 19th century.
Great Britain -- Social conditions -- 19th century.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Elementary reactions of the lower paraffins. --.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Man's earliest attempts were to classify the different kinds of matter. The ancient alchemists worked in a murky atmosphere of superstition and mysticism but from this the qualitative classification slowly took shape. Through their endless trial and error experiments, the different substances and their properties became known, as well as their modes of reaction and methods for their preparation. [...] The type of investigation has changed from the study of processes with more than one reactant, to processes where the decomposition of one simple molecule is involved, from this to reactions of atoms and free radicals; all in the hope of establishing the fundamentals whereby the mechanisms of much more complex reactions may be explained. For purposes of investigation the lower hydrocarbons have been favored, since they are gaseous and relatively simple, and constitute an ideal proving ground for free radical mechanisms. They are satisfactory for the further reason that once an acceptable mechanism has been developed for a simple member, the next member of the series presents an opportunity for repeating the work with a more complex yet similar molecule, which is a step in the direction of the ultimate goal of mechanisms for complex reactions. What follows is a review of work done along these lines, and will serve to introduce the work which is the subject of this thesis, and form a basis for interpreting its results. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.
